name: Berlin
intro_vibe: The Capital of Cool: Where history meets counterculture.

general_info.description: Berlin is the capital and largest city of Germany. A city of contrasts, Berlin blends a tumultuous history with cutting-edge creativity. From the remnants of the Wall to world-class museums and legendary nightlife, Berlin is raw, real, and unapologetically alternative.

weather_breakdown.name: December
pros: New Year's Eve at Brandenburg Gate

etiquette_tips: Cash is King: Many places still don't accept cards. Always carry cash (Barzahlung).
Sunday Quiet: Most shops are closed on Sundays. Plan ahead!
Pfand System: Return bottles for a deposit refund (usually 25 cents). Look for the 'Pfand' symbol.
Directness: Germans are blunt and honest. It's not rude—it's efficient.
Jaywalking: Don't cross on red, even if no cars are coming. You'll get judged.

neighborhoods.name: Kreuzberg
neighborhoods.description: The heart of Berlin's counterculture. Street art, Turkish markets, punk bars, and late-night döner kebabs.

neighborhoods.name: Friedrichshain
neighborhoods.description: Home to the legendary Berghain club and the East Side Gallery. Raw, industrial, and unapologetically hedonistic.

neighborhoods.name: Mitte
neighborhoods.description: Berlin's official center with major landmarks, museums, and upscale shopping. Tourist-heavy but essential.

neighborhoods.name: Prenzlauer Berg
neighborhoods.description: Once bohemian, now filled with young families, organic cafes, and vintage shops. Still charming.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: The U-Bahn and S-Bahn are your lifelines. Efficient, fast, and covers the whole city.
details: U-Bahn (Metro): 10 lines, runs until 1am weekdays, 24/7 on weekends.
S-Bahn (Train): Above-ground, connects suburbs and airports.
Trams & Buses: Extensive network, especially in former East Berlin.
Tickets: Buy a day pass (Tageskarte) or weekly pass. Validate before boarding!

logistics.title: Scams to Avoid
logistics.summary: Berlin is generally safe, but watch out for these common scams.
details: Fake Ticket Inspectors: Real inspectors wear red armbands with 'BVG' badges.
Club Entrance Fees: Some clubs charge exorbitant 'guest list' fees. Research beforehand.
Pickpockets: Active on crowded U-Bahn lines (U2, U8) and tourist spots.

logistics.title: Safety Basics
logistics.summary: Berlin is safe, but use common sense in certain areas.
details: Görlitzer Park: Avoid after dark. Drug dealers are common.
Night: Most areas are safe, but avoid empty parks and U-Bahn stations late at night.
Bikes: Lock your bike with a heavy-duty lock. Bike theft is rampant.

logistics.title: Apps to Download
logistics.summary: These apps will make your Berlin trip smoother.
details: BVG Fahrinfo: Official transit app for U-Bahn, S-Bahn, trams, and buses.
Resident Advisor: Essential for finding the best club nights.
Lieferando: Food delivery (better than Uber Eats here).
Google Translate: Download German offline pack.

must_eat.description: Berlin's iconic street food: grilled pork sausage topped with curry ketchup and paprika. Best enjoyed at a late-night Imbiss (snack stand).
The most famous döner in Berlin. Expect a 1-hour line, but it's worth it. Grilled veggies, feta, and secret sauce in fresh bread.
Breaded and fried veal or pork cutlet, served with potato salad or fries. A German classic found in every beer hall.
The caffeinated yerba mate drink of Berlin's club scene. Sweet, fizzy, and keeps you dancing until 6am.
Traditional Bavarian beer hall in Berlin. Massive steins, hearty food, and oompah music. Touristy but fun.
A jelly-filled doughnut, not to be confused with the American 'Berliner'. John F. Kennedy famously said 'Ich bin ein Berliner' (I am a jelly doughnut).

items.description: The most iconic symbol of Berlin and German reunification. A neoclassical triumphal arch that has witnessed centuries of history.
Germany's parliament building with a stunning glass dome designed by Norman Foster. Free entry but book ahead.
Berlin's tallest structure and a GDR-era icon. The observation deck offers 360° views of the city.
The longest remaining section of the Berlin Wall, now an open-air gallery with murals by artists from around the world.
The famous Cold War crossing point between East and West Berlin. Now a touristy photo op, but historically significant.

items.name_en: Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe
items.name_local: Denkmal für die ermordeten Juden Europas
items.description: A haunting field of 2,711 concrete slabs. A powerful and somber tribute to Holocaust victims.
A UNESCO World Heritage site with five world-renowned museums, including the Pergamon and Neues Museum.
A chilling documentation center built on the site of the former Gestapo and SS headquarters. Free entry.
